questions.text: Which of the following foods has the maximum biological value?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option D) Egg

Egg

Importance
  • Eggs are highly nutritious and rich in protein, essential vitamins, & minerals.
  • They support muscle building, brain health, and overall wellness.
  • NPU of egg is 96 (~ almost equal to 100)

Rule of 6
  • 6 grams of protein
  • 6 grams of fat
  • 60 calories per large egg
  • 6 essential vitamins (A, B2, B12, D, E, K)
  • 60 grams average weight

Others:

  • 6x5=30 mg Calcium
  • 6x0.25=1.5mg Iron

questions.text: Which of the following food items contains the lowest amount of iron?
Which statement is correct regarding the reference woman represents the average healthy woman's nutritional needs and is used as a standard for setting the RDA ?
questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ reference woman
  • ↳ Recommended Dietary Allowance (RDA)
  • ↳ Weight 55 kgs : The reference woman is typically assumed to have a body weight of 55 kg (121 lbs). This value is used to determine the average energy and nutrient requirements.
  • ↳ Weight 55 kgs : The reference woman is typically assumed to have a body weight of 55 kg (121 lbs). This value is used to determine the average energy and nutrient requirements.
  • ↳ Weight 55 kgs
  • ↳ 55 kg
  • ↳ Height 1.73 m (Option B) : While height is a factor in determining nutritional needs, the reference woman is generally assumed to have a height of around 1.60 m (not 1.73 m).
  • ↳ Height 1.73 m (Option B)
  • ↳ 1.60 m
  • ↳ Works 10 hours/day (Option C) : The reference woman is not assumed to work for a specific number of hours each day. Nutritional requirements can vary depending on physical activity, but the reference is typically for a woman with moderate activity levels.
  • ↳ Works 10 hours/day (Option C)
  • ↳ Age of 18-25 years (Option D) : The reference woman is not specifically limited to this age range. Nutritional needs are assessed based on a range of factors, including age, but the reference woman is generally used as an average for adult women (not limited to a specific age group).
  • ↳ Age of 18-25 years (Option D)

questions.text: What is the most relevant information that should be obtained from the medical history of a patient from Chhattisgarh who is experiencing gradual muscle weakness and spasms in the legs, and exhibits only motor impairment upon examination?

options.label: A
options.text: History of similar illness in the past

questions.explanation:
Feature

Findings

Cause

Excessive consumption of Lathyrus sativus (Khesari dal)

Region

Endemic in Chhattisgarh, Madhya Pradesh, Bihar, Odisha

Symptoms

Gradual-onset spastic paraparesis, hyperreflexia

Sensory Involvement

Absent (pure motor disorder)

Prevention

Dietary restriction, government bans on Khesari dal

questions.text: Which of the following factors can contribute to the development of malnutrition?
questions.explanation:
Infection

Effect on Nutrition

Diarrheal diseases

Causes fluid and nutrient loss, leading to dehydration and malabsorption.

Tuberculosis (TB)

Increases catabolism (muscle breakdown), leading to weight loss.

Parasitic infections (e.g., hookworm, giardiasis)

Causes iron deficiency anemia, protein loss, and malabsorption.

Measles

Leads to vitamin A deficiency, impairing immune function.

questions.text: What is the likely reason for the food poisoning experienced by the worker in the groundnut factory who consumed spoiled groundnuts that were stored in the facility?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer D - Aflatoxins

Clinical features
  • Features of hepatotoxicity (jaundice, hepatomegaly)
  • Hepatocellular carcinoma

Causative agent
  • Infestation of Aspergillus flavus and Aspergillus parasiticus over stored rice, wheat, and corn
  • Produce mycotoxins: aflatoxin B1 & G1 (both are hepatotoxic & carcinogenic)

Risk factors
  • Storage temperature of 11 to 37 degree Celsius
  • Moisture content >16%

Prevention
  • Educating people
  • Moisture content <10% during storage

questions.text: What vitamin deficiency leads to xerophthalmia, a condition characterized by dryness of the eyes?
You are administering vitamin A supplements to an 8-month-old infant for two consecutive days. What is the recommended dose?

A poor farmer with a history of successive crop failure develops progressive spastic paraparesis, signs of upper motor neuron paralysis, and gait instability. Name the toxin responsible for this condition.
questions.explanation:
Causative agent
  • Beta-oxalyl amino alanine (BOAA) present in Lathyrus sativus
  • Significant exposure : >30% inclusion in diet over 2-6 months

Clinical features
  • Latent stage: preventive can be best implemented here
  • No stick stage: most common point of diagnosis
  • One-stick stage: muscular stiffness begins
  • Two-stick stage: will need crutches
  • Crawler stage: muscular atrophy sets in.

Treatment
  • Vitamin C prophylaxis: 500-1000 mg per day
  • Banning the crop

Toxin removal
  • Steeping method: soaking in hot water for 2 hours, drained and sun-dried.
  • Parboiling: overnight soaking in limewater.
  • Genetic approach: selecting variants with less BOAA content and cultivating the same.
  • Educating people.
  • Bringing socio-economic changes.

questions.text: Who is responsible for counseling and providing information to the patient, a 30-week primigravida experiencing reduced vision at night, who has been avoiding certain fruits during her pregnancy due to concerns about their potential abortifacient effects?
questions.explanation:
ASHA (Accredited Social Health Activist)

ASHA is a woman (married, divorced, or widowed) resident of the village, aged 25-45 years, with education up to 8th grade.

Population Norm for ASHA

The general norm is 1 ASHA per 1000 population. In tribal, hilly, and desert areas, this may be relaxed to 1 ASHA per habitation.

Role and Responsibilities of ASHA
  • Health Activist: Create awareness and provide information on health determinants, existing services, and the importance of health and family welfare.
  • Counselor: Provide counseling on birth preparedness, safe delivery, and family planning.
  • Mobilizer: Help the community access health services, such as immunizations, sanitation, and nutrition.
  • Provider: Offer basic care for common illnesses and first-aid, and act as a depot for essential medications.
  • Community Engagement: Work with village health committees and panchayats for planning and awareness.

Specific Responsibilities of ASHA
  • Promote health and sanitation practices.
  • Advise on child care, immunization, and reproductive health.
  • Assist with family planning and treatment of minor ailments.
  • Mobilize pregnant women and children to health services
  • Provide basic medical care and support for diarrhea, fever, and tuberculosis (under DOTS).
  • Serve as a depot holder for essential drugs and medical supplies.

Role and Integration with Anganwadi

The Anganwadi worker helps guide ASHA, particularly in organizing Health Day activities, mobilizing village women and children, and promoting nutrition and health education.

Role and Integration with ANMs (Auxiliary Nurse Midwives)

 

ANMs guide ASHA in areas like immunization, safe pregnancy, and health education, and assist in organizing Health Days. ANMs also help with training and monitor ASHA's performance.

Toxin removal

  • Genetic approach: selecting variants with less BOAA content and cultivating the same.
  • Educating people.
  • Bringing socio-economic changes.

questions.text: A man presented with bilateral swelling of his legs, diarrhoea, and dyspnea. He has a history of consuming mustard oil from a local vendor. Which test should be performed by the health inspector to check for the adulterant?
questions.explanation:
Clinical features

Bilateral leg swelling, diarrhoea, dyspnoea, features of glaucoma and heart failure even up to death.

Causative agent

Sanguinarine (toxic alkaloid present in argemone oil).

Detection of contamination
  • Nitric acid test: the presence of a red-brown ring when added to the sample oil indicates the presence of argemone oil.
  • Paper chromatography test. Most sensitive and better than nitric acid test (Option A) (Option B ruled out)

Prevention
  • Accidental contamination: removing argemone weeds growing among oilseed crops.
  • Deliberate contamination: enforcing Prevention of Food Adulteration Act.

questions.explanation:
Cobalamin - vitamin B12

Sources

Liver; Meat; Milk; Eggs; Cheese; Synthesised by gut bacteria (not found in food of vegetable origin)

Absorption

Absorbed in terminal ileum, bound to intrinsic factor.

Uses

It helps in the synthesis of fatty acid(myelin) and DNA.

Deficiency

  • Megaloblastic anemia
  • Demyelinating lesion in the spinal cord
  • Infertility

Requirements
  • Adults: 2-2 mcg/day.
  • Pregnancy: extra 0.25 mcg.
  • Lactation: extra 1 mcg.
  • Infants and children: 1.2 mcg.

questions.text: What is the most commonly used method of pasteurization nowadays?

options.label: C
options.text: High temperature and short time method

options.label: D
options.text: Low temperature and long time method

questions.correct_answer: C. High temperature and short time method
questions.explanation:
Correct Option C

Pasteurization Method

Description

High Temperature Short Time (HTST)

In HTST pasteurization, the product is heated to a high temperature (usually around 72°C to 74°C) for a short period of time (typically 15 to 30 seconds). This method helps to eliminate harmful pathogens while preserving the flavor and nutritional qualities of the product. It is commonly used for milk and dairy products.

Low Temperature Long Time (LTLT)

LTLT pasteurization involves heating the product at a lower temperature (usually around 63°C) for a longer duration (typically 30 minutes). This method is commonly used for certain juices, as well as beer and wine, to destroy spoilage microorganisms while minimizing the impact on flavor and quality.

Ultra-High Temperature (UHT)

UHT pasteurization involves heating the product at a very high temperature (usually around 135°C to 150°C) for a very short time (2 to 5 seconds). This process effectively kills both harmful bacteria and spoilage microorganisms, extending the shelf life of the product without the need for refrigeration until opened. UHT pasteurization is commonly used for products like milk, cream, and fruit juices.

Batch (Vat) Pasteurization

Batch pasteurization, also known as vat pasteurization, involves heating the product in a batch or vat to a specific temperature (usually around 63°C to 66°C) for a predetermined time (typically 30 minutes). It is commonly used for small-scale or artisanal production of dairy products, such as cheese, to achieve the desired level of microbial safety while preserving the product's unique characteristics.

Ultra-Short Time (UST) Pasteurization

UST pasteurization is a newer method that utilizes high-frequency electric fields to rapidly heat and cool the product. It involves exposing the product to pulsed electric fields for a very short time (less than a second), effectively eliminating pathogens and extending shelf life. UST pasteurization is still being researched and developed for commercial applications.

questions.text: What is the most effective way to assess chronic malnutrition in a child?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option C:

References:

  • ↳ The best evaluation for chronic malnutrition in a child is done by assessing the height for age.
  • ↳ Height for age, also known as stunting, is a commonly used indicator to assess chronic malnutrition in children. It measures the child's height in relation to their age and compares it to standardized growth charts or reference populations. This indicator provides valuable information about the child's long-term nutritional status and growth trajectory.
  • ↳ Chronic malnutrition refers to the condition where a child experiences prolonged inadequate nutrient intake, which can lead to impaired growth and development.
  • ↳ Height for age reflects the cumulative effects of undernutrition over time, indicating whether a child has experienced stunted growth compared to their peers of the same age.
  • ↳ Incorrect Options:
  • ↳ Incorrect Options:
  • ↳ Option A . Weight for height: Weight for height, also known as wasting or acute malnutrition, is used to assess acute nutritional status and is more indicative of recent weight loss or inadequate weight gain. It is not the most appropriate indicator for evaluating chronic malnutrition.
  • ↳ Option A
  • ↳ Option B: Weight for age: Weight for age is a commonly used indicator to assess underweight or general malnutrition. It compares a child's weight to the average weight of children of the same age. While it can provide insights into overall nutritional status, it is not specific to chronic malnutrition.
  • ↳ Option B:
  • ↳ Option D . Ponderal index: Ponderal index is calculated by dividing the weight in kilograms by the cube of the height in meters. It is used to assess body composition and can provide information about body proportionality. However, it is not specifically used to evaluate chronic malnutrition.
  • ↳ Option D
    • Markers for Malnutrition

    Acute malnutrition

    • Low weight for height
    • Measure of emaciation/wasting

    Chronic malnutrition

    • Low height for age
    • Measure of stunting

    Acute on chronic malnutrition

    • Low weight for age
    • Measure for underweight

questions.text: Which of the following is not employed in evaluating body fat?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option D: B

Assessment Method

BODY FAT ASSESSMENT

Body Mass Index (BMI)

Calculated by dividing an individual's weight (in kilograms) by the square of their height (in meters).

Dual-Energy X-ray Absorptiometry (DXA)

A precise method that measures body composition, including bone mineral density, lean mass, and fat mass, using low-dose X-rays.

Skinfold Thickness Measurement

Measures the thickness of subcutaneous fat at specific sites on the body using calipers.

Bioelectrical Impedance Analysis (BIA)

Uses electrical impedance to estimate body composition. A low-level electrical current is passed through the body, measuring resistance.

Air Displacement Plethysmography (ADP)

Involves measuring body volume and density by sitting inside a small chamber that uses air displacement.

Hydrostatic Weighing

Determines body density by measuring a person's weight while submerged underwater.

Near-Infrared Interactance

Measures the reflection and absorption of near-infrared light to estimate body fat content.

Waist Circumference

Measures the circumference of the waist, providing an indirect indicator of abdominal fat and health risks.

questions.text: What is the purpose of administering ORS plus Zinc to a patient from a rural village?
Beri-Beri seen in?
questions.explanation:
Aspect

BERI BERI

Definition

Beriberi is a condition resulting from a deficiency of thiamine (vitamin B1) in the body.

Types

 

1. Wet beriberi: Affects the cardiovascular system, causing heart failure and edema (swelling).

2. Dry beriberi: Affects the nervous system, leading to muscle weakness, tingling, and coordination issues.
3. Infantile beriberi: Affects infants 2-4 months breast-fed by thiamine deficient mother

Causes

Inadequate intake of thiamine-rich foods, such as whole grains, legumes, nuts, and pork.

Risk Factors

 

1. Poor diet lacking in essential nutrients, especially thiamine.

2. Alcoholism: Alcohol can interfere with thiamine absorption and increase its excretion.

Symptoms

 

1. Wet beriberi: Shortness of breath, rapid heart rate, fatigue, swelling, and enlarged heart.

2. Dry beriberi: Muscle weakness, peripheral neuropathy, loss of coordination, and weight loss.
3.Infantile beriberi: Shows signs of peripheral neuropathy

Diagnosis

Medical history, physical examination, assessment of symptoms, blood tests to measure thiamine levels.

Treatment

Thiamine supplementation through oral or intravenous administration, improvement of diet quality.

Prevention

Adequate thiamine intake through a balanced diet, especially foods rich in thiamine.

Complications

If left untreated, beriberi can lead to severe complications, including heart failure or Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome.

questions.text: A community medicine student was required to discuss the various natural sources of Vitamin A. Among the options listed below, which one offers the highest concentration of Vitamin A naturally?
Which is the most suitable indicator to determine the nutritional value of protein?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option  A

References:

  • ↳ Serum albumin is a protein produced by the liver and is the most abundant protein in the blood. It plays a crucial role in maintaining osmotic pressure, transporting substances such as hormones and drugs, and regulating fluid balance in the body. Serum albumin also contributes to the transport and distribution of various nutrients, including fatty acids, vitamins, and minerals.
  • ↳ It plays a crucial role in maintaining osmotic pressure, transporting substances such as hormones and drugs, and regulating fluid balance in the body. Serum albumin also contributes to the transport and distribution of various nutrients, including fatty acids, vitamins, and minerals.
  • ↳ It plays a crucial role in maintaining osmotic pressure, transporting substances such as hormones and drugs, and regulating fluid balance in the body.
  • ↳ Serum albumin also contributes to the transport and distribution of various nutrients, including fatty acids, vitamins, and minerals.
  • ↳ Serum albumin concentration is commonly measured through blood tests, and it serves as an important indicator of nutritional status and overall health. Low serum albumin levels may indicate malnutrition, liver disease, kidney disease, or chronic inflammation. High serum albumin levels are less common and may be seen in conditions such as dehydration or severe burns.
  • ↳ Low serum albumin levels may indicate malnutrition, liver disease, kidney disease, or chronic inflammation. High serum albumin levels are less common and may be seen in conditions such as dehydration or severe burns.
  • ↳ Low serum albumin levels may indicate malnutrition, liver disease, kidney disease, or chronic inflammation.
  • ↳ High serum albumin levels are less common and may be seen in conditions such as dehydration or severe burns.
  • ↳ Serum albumin concentration is influenced by various factors: Nutritional status: Inadequate protein intake or malnutrition can lead to low serum albumin levels. Liver function: Liver diseases such as cirrhosis or hepatitis can affect albumin production and result in decreased levels. Kidney function: Impaired kidney function may affect albumin excretion and result in increased or decreased levels depending on the underlying cause. Inflammation and chronic diseases: Inflammatory conditions, such as infections or autoimmune diseases, can cause changes in serum albumin concentration.
  • ↳ Nutritional status: Inadequate protein intake or malnutrition can lead to low serum albumin levels. Liver function: Liver diseases such as cirrhosis or hepatitis can affect albumin production and result in decreased levels. Kidney function: Impaired kidney function may affect albumin excretion and result in increased or decreased levels depending on the underlying cause. Inflammation and chronic diseases: Inflammatory conditions, such as infections or autoimmune diseases, can cause changes in serum albumin concentration.
  • ↳ Nutritional status: Inadequate protein intake or malnutrition can lead to low serum albumin levels.
  • ↳ Liver function: Liver diseases such as cirrhosis or hepatitis can affect albumin production and result in decreased levels.
  • ↳ Kidney function: Impaired kidney function may affect albumin excretion and result in increased or decreased levels depending on the underlying cause.
  • ↳ Inflammation and chronic diseases: Inflammatory conditions, such as infections or autoimmune diseases, can cause changes in serum albumin concentration.
  • ↳ Monitoring serum albumin concentration can help assess nutritional status, evaluate liver and kidney function, and monitor response to treatment in various medical conditions.
  • ↳ Normal serum albumin levels typically range between 3.5 to 5.5 grams per deciliter (g/dL) or 35 to 55 grams per liter (g/L), although specific reference ranges may vary depending on the laboratory and population.
